abstract.para: The following document provides an overview of &sls; JeOS and describes the setup procedure.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &jeos; (Just enough Operating System) refers to a minimal customizable operating system that specifically tailored for a specific usage scenario (for example, a container host, a virtual machine guest, an appliance base, or a small server image) The purpose of &jeos; is to make the system as small as possible, while providing the option of installing additional software. This allows you to tailor systems for use in a data center, or create desired virtual application images or appliances. You can choose what packages and components to install based on a specific use case. To that end, &jeos; provides access to all regular software repositories.

If you have &sls; certification, you are automatically certified for &jeos;, as it is derived from the same code base. &sls; &jeos; allows you to reduce the operating system to the packages essential for the specific usage scenario. This minimizes the number of packages and patches that have to be managed and applied. By removing unnecessary packages, you also reduce the number of potential vulnerabilities, thus making the resulting system more secure. Reducing the system's footprint also results in lower resource consumption and improved performance.

&jeos; is delivered as pre-configured and ready-to-run virtual machine images. The system comes with the jeos-firstboot wizard for configuring system locales and root password during the first boot. &jeos; ships with the SSH server enabled and excluded from the firewall configuration. The spplied Kiwi templates make it possible to create customized &jeos; images.
&jeos; provides ready to deploy server images on the x86_64 architecture for the following usage scenarios:

listitem.para: KVM/Xen with HVM
Xen Paravirtualized
Microsoft Hyper-V
VMware
OpenStack Cloud

sect2.title: Differences between &jeos; and &sls;
sect2.para: There are several significant differences between &jeos; and &sls;.

listitem.para: &jeos; comes with the jeos-firstboot tool that can be used to configure basic settings during the first boot. This includes keyboard layout and language, time zone, and root password.
The default network configuration is set to use DHCP, and the system automatically creates a Btrfs snapshot of the initial configuration.
Because of size constraints, &jeos; images use the kernel-default-base as the default kernel. Since the kernel does not contain drivers for bare metal, this allows for a smaller footprint.

If your specific situation requires any of the omitted modules, install the kernel-default package to get a full tree of the kernel modules. This is the same kernel used by a regular &sls; installation.
When installing a &sls; from the installation media, the system automatically sets the installation media as the default offline channel.
&jeos; has no channel by default, and you have to register your system to access our online channels. Refer to for further information.

&jeos; is a slimmed-down version of &sls;. The reduction in size is achieved in part by enabling two options in /etc/zypp/zypp.conf: rpm.install.excludedocs = yes (excludes all files marked as documentation from being installed by default) and solver.onlyRequires = true (disables installation of suggested and recommended packages by default).

&jeos; images are built using the &kiwi; tool. &kiwi;'s configuration files explicitly list packages that must be included in the images. Keep in mind that these base packages pull their dependencies during the image building process. Therefore, the list of preinstalled packages in an images usually contains more packages than the list of base packages.
The &kiwi; configuration files used to create the official &jeos; images are available from the openSUSE Build Service at https://build.opensuse.org/.

note.title: Specific host tools packages
note.para: Each &sls; &jeos; flavors will contain certain host tools package. Please refer to the specific flavors section in this documentation for more details

listitem.para: Unlike &sls;, which calculates the disk layout during installation, &jeos; feature fixed virtual image partitioning scheme as follows:
2MB BIOS boot
33MB EFI System
24GB Linux filesystem

To get additional disk space, you can either extend the existing disk from the virtual host or add a secondary disk to the virtual machine. If you choose to add another disk, you have partition and format it manually.

important.title: Supported Virtualization Hosts (Hypervisors)
important.para: &jeos; can run as a virtualization guest on the same virtualization hosts (hypervisors) as &sls;. See for more info on what hypervisors are supported. Refer also to for information on specific host tools.

sect2.title: &jeos; Image for OpenStack Cloud
sect2.para: As the name suggests, &jeos; for OpenStack Cloud is an image designed specifically for use in an OpenStack environment.
Instead of the jeos-firstboot tool, &jeos; for OpenStack Cloud uses cloud-init for configuring the image. The image also uses the XFS file system and the following kernel configuration:
This means that the image ships without packages required by jeos-firstboot and Btrfs.
&jeos; for OpenStack Cloud comes includes several OpenStack-related packages, such as cloud-init, cloud-init-config-suse, and xfsprogs.

important.title: Images started with qemu
important.para: In case you start an image directly with qemu-kvm on a SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 host, the virtual BIOS will not provide a system UUID. Such a UUID is used when registering systems with SUSEConnect. In case a system is registered without a UUID, it cannot be properly tracked and may not have access to all repositories.
